name: butter production, from cow milk | butter, from cow milk | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/10559/documentation

Butter is a dairy product made by churning fresh or fermented cream or milk. This activity covers main flows related to butter production from milk. ;The process of buttermaking is basically a mechanical one in which milk and later on cream, an emulsion of oil in water, is transformed to butter, an emulsion of water in oil. This is achieved by a process of batch or continuous churning.

This activity starts when the milk enters the dairy gate.

This activity end when the finished product - butter - is ready to leave the gates of the dairy. Packaging is not included in this inventory.
category: C:Manufacturing/10:Manufacture of food products/105:Manufacture of dairy products/1050:Manufacture of dairy products

processDocumentation.technologyDescription: A number of continuous techniques are available such as methods in which milk and later on cream is subjected to high speed churning and continuous working. The main steps of buttermaking are always the same.  ;Scheme of butter manufacture from cream (EU Commission, IPPC, 2006, Reference Document on Best Available Techniques in the Food, Drink and Milk Industries). This sheme does not include the previous step; milk to cream production, while this dataset does.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: This dataset was created based on literature data (Nilsson K., 2010, Comparative life cycle assessment of margarine and butter consumed in the UK, Germany and France) which present data collected at dairies in Denmark and Germany,

flow.name: butter, from cow milk
flow.category: C:Manufacturing/10:Manufacture of food products/105:Manufacture of dairy products/1050:Manufacture of dairy products

exchanges.description:
Calculated value. 

Wastewater from potato starch production is a proxy for the wastewater from butter production for which data are not available.

The amount of wastewater is calculated as difference between the amount of tap water entering the process and the amount of water which is consumed in th process (evaporates).

Cross referenced; according to literature (Djekic, 2013, Environmental life-cycle assessment of various dairy products) the amount of wastewater produced when producing butter is between 6.41 - 9.61 l/kg.

exchanges.description:
Literature value.

kg of Fat and Protein Corrected Milk. FPCM is 4.0% fat and 3.3% true protein content. Conversion to FPCM is as follow, according to the International Dairy Federation: FPCM (kg/yr) = Production (kg/yr) x [0.1226 x Fat% + 0.0776 x Protein% + 0.2534]

flow.name: Water
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/unspecified

exchanges.description:
Calculated based on literature data (Schmid, A.; 2010, Bachelor-Thesis; Carbon Footprint von Schweizer KÃ¤se, supervised by T.Nemecek, Agroscope).

20 years is the lifetime of a dairy
(18*10*3=) 540m3 is the volume of the dairy
18.9 l of milk is needed to produce 1kg of butter
2.2E6 kg/year is the amount of milk proccessed annually in the dairy of volume of 540m3.
